course.labs.modernartui

Class ModernArtUIActivity

  • java.lang.Object
    • Activity
      • course.labs.modernartui.ModernArtUIActivity
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    MoreInformationDialog.DialogListener

    public class ModernArtUIActivity
extends Activity
implements MoreInformationDialog.DialogListener
    "Coursera" | "Programming Mobile Applications for Android Handheld Systems" | Lab: "Modern Art UI"

    Lab description:
    A simple application that creates and displays a user interface, presents a "menu" and a "dialog", and that opens a link to an external website. Specifically, this application's user interface is composed of geometric shapes arranged in a particular order. It has one area containing multiple colored rectangles and another one containing a "SeekBar" (sometimes called a "Slider"). When the user drags the "SeekBar", all non-white / non-gray rectangles gradually change their color. This application also contains an (overflow) "options" menu. When the user clicks on the "options" menu an option labeled, "More Information" should appear. When the user clicks on the "More Information" option, a "Dialog" should appear displaying some text and two buttons. If the user clicks on the "Not Now" button in the "Dialog", the "Dialog" should be dismissed. If the user clicks on the "Visit MOMA" button, then the "Web Browser" should be opened to view a web page on the "MoMA.org" web site.

    Lab requirements:
    The application must implement all the functions described above, but can vary in the visual layout as long as:
    - 1) user interface displays at least 5 separate colored rectangles, at least one of these rectangles is "white" / "gray" in color, and at least one of these rectangles is "non-white" / "non-gray" in color [*].
    - 2) it includes a "SeekBar".
    - 3) dragging this app's "SeekBar", the colored rectangles change color.
    - 4) it allows the user to view an "options" menu displaying the text, "More Information".
    - 5) when the user clicks on the "More Information" option, the app presents a "Dialog" with two buttons labeled "Visit MOMA" and "Not Now".
    - 6) when the user clicks on the "Dialog" button labeled, "Not Now", the "Dialog" disappears.
    - 7) when the user clicks on the "Dialog" button labeled, "Visit MOMA", a browser opens displaying a page at the "www.moma.org" web site.

    [*]: application's user interface is composed of five (5) colored rectangles. In practice, the rectangle with a "white" background color is randomly selected each time the application starts. The background color of each of the remaining (four) rectangles is randomly selected each time the application starts.

    Notes:
    - the app has been tested on the emulator using a "Google Galaxy Nexus AVD - 4.3" with "API" level 18 (screen resolution: 720 x 1280). To limit configuration problems, you should test the app against a similar AVD.
    - keep also in mind that the "Genymotion" Android emulator used. Have a look at:
    https://www.genymotion.com/
    - the project has been created, developed and configured on "Android Studio" IDE. Have a look at:
    http://developer.android.com/tools/studio/index.html
    - screencast video of the app in action can be found at:
    https://youtu.be/bWY8zdC_AvM
    Since:
    2015-06-04
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Aristotelis Metsinis (aristotelis.metsinis@gmail.com)
    See Also:
    http://aristotelis-metsinis.github.io/

        Parameters:
        savedInstanceState - If the "activity" is being re-initialized after previously being shut down then this "Bundle" contains the data it most recently supplied in "onSaveInstanceState(Bundle)". Otherwise it is null.

      • onOptionsItemSelected

        public boolean onOptionsItemSelected(MenuItem item)
        Called whenever an item in "options" menu is selected. This method is overridden to handle action bar item clicks.
        Parameters:
        item - The "menu" item that was selected.
        Returns:
        boolean - "true" to handle "menu" processing in this method or "false" to allow normal "menu" processing to proceed.

      • onDialogPositiveClick

        public void onDialogPositiveClick(DialogFragment dialog)
        This "activity" hosts a "dialog" by creating an instance of the "dialog" with the "dialog" fragment's constructor and receives the dialog's events through an implementation of the "DialogListener" interface. So, the "dialog" fragment receives a reference to this "activity" through the "Fragment.onAttach()" callback, which it uses to call the following method defined by the "MoreInformationDialog.DialogListener" interface.
        Specified by:
        onDialogPositiveClick in interface MoreInformationDialog.DialogListener
        Parameters:
        dialog - "DialogFragment" in case this host "activity" needs to query it.

      • onSaveInstanceState

        public void onSaveInstanceState(Bundle savedInstanceState)
        When an "Activity" (fragment) is being killed, but may be restarted later, Android calls "onSaveInstanceState()". This gives the "Activity" a chance to save any per-instance data (to a "Bundle"; a collection of key-value pairs) it may need if the "Activity" is later restored. In this case, it saves the background colors of the rectangles; actually the "HashMap" object that stores those colors (acting as "values") for each of those rectangles (acting as "keys").
        Parameters:
        savedInstanceState - "Bundle" in which to place the saved state.

      • initialiseBackgroundColors

        private java.util.HashMap initialiseBackgroundColors()
        Helper method used for the initialisation of the background color of each of the rectangles of application's user interface. Application's user interface is composed of five (5) colored rectangles. The rectangle with a "white" background color is randomly selected each time the application starts. The background color of each of the remaining (four) rectangles is randomly selected each time the application starts.
        Returns:
        "HashMap" object that stores the background colors (acting as "values") of application's UI rectangles (acting as "keys").

        view - Applications' UI "View".
        backgroundColor - The background color to be set.

      • updateBackgroundColor

        private void updateBackgroundColor(View view,
                         int backgroundColor,
                         int progress)
        Helper method; update the background color of a "View" component based upon the progress level of a "SeekBar".
        Parameters:
        view - Applications' UI "View".
        backgroundColor - The (argb) background color to be updated.
        progress - The current "SeekBar" progress level.
